doc.after: On Friday 28Â June 1816 at 9Â am, the condemned men, William Beamiss, George Crow, John Dennis, Isaac Harley and Thomas South, were driven from the gaol at Ely market place in a black-draped cart[124] and twoÂ horses costing five-pound five-shillings[123] (Â£351) accompanied by the bishop's gaol chaplain, John Griffin,[125] in a hired chaise and pair costing 13Â shillings (Â£43).[126] In submitting his expenses on 29Â June, chief bailiff F. Bagge noted "We have no power of pressing a cart for the purpose, and 'tis a difficult matter to get one, people feel's so much upon the occasion".[123]
